children.name: talk to yourself
children.definition: tự nói chuyện một mình
examples: I think he’s going crazy - he talks to himself all the time.
Betty was talking to herself under her breath as she worked.

children.name: think aloud
children.definition: / think out loud to say aloud what you are thinking, without meaning to talk to anyone else: nói ra suy nghĩ của mình
examples: ‘I don’t follow you.’ ‘That’s OK. I’m just thinking out loud.’
She began to think aloud as she always did when she was faced with a difficult problem.

children.name: speech
children.definition: /spiːtʃ/
examples: ▪ Only humans are capable of speech.
▪ The left side of the brain controls speech.

children.name: thing to say
children.definition: /ˌθɪŋ tə ˈseɪ/ lời gì để nói
examples: a strange/stupid/horrible etc thing to say : lời nói kì lạ/ngu ngốc/tệ hại
a remark that is strange, stupid etc:
▪ What an awful thing to say about your mother!
▪ I know it’s a terrible thing to say, but sometimes I wish I’d never been born.

children.name: point
children.definition: /pɔɪnt/  something you say, that people had not thought about or discussed until you mentioned it: nhắc đến, ý kiến , luận điểm
examples: point about: nhắc đến về
▪ Michael’s point about training is an interesting one.
good point: ý kiến hay
▪ That’s a good point, and we should take it into consideration.
make a point : nêu ý kiến
say something in a discussion, which people had not thought of before
▪ In his speech, Marks made the point that far more people died from smoking tobacco than from taking drugs.

children.name: say
children.definition: to express an idea, feeling, thought etc using words :
examples: ‘I’m so tired,’ she said.
‘Don’t cry,’ he said softly.
Don’t believe anything he says.
say (that)
A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.
I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.
say how/why/who etc
Did she say what happened?
I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.
‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – shedidn’t say.’
say something to somebody
What did you say to her?
a terrible/silly/strange etc thing to say
What a silly thing to say!
say hello/goodbye/thank you etc(= say something to greet someone, thank someone etc )
She left without saying goodbye.
say you’re sorry(= apologize )
I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?
say yes/no (to something)(= agree or refuse )
Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!
say nothing/anything/something (about something)
He looked as if he was going to say something.
I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.
have anything/nothing/something to say
Does anyone else have anything to say?
Although he didn’tsay so, it was clear that he was in pain.
What makes you say that(= why do you think that )?
say to do something(= tell someone to do something )
Nina said to meet her at 4.30.
I’d like tosay a few words(= make a short speech ).
‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’
Grammar
You cannot 'say someone something' or 'say someone to do something'. Usetell:
She told me (NOT said me) something shocking.
He told me (NOT said me) to sit down.
You cansay something about somethingbut you cannot 'say about something'. Usetalk:
He did not talk about (NOT say about) his feelings.

Register:In written English, people often avoid usingsaywhen referring to opinions or ideas expressed by another writer. Instead, they prefer to use a more formal verb such asargue,assert,claim, ormaintain.

children.name: put
children.definition: to say or write sth using words in a particular way : diễn đạt
examples: Has everyone had a chance to put their point of view?
as sb puts it
When women joined the organization, it ‘took on a new look',asnews reportsput it.
We're going to have to work very hard, butasChris so succinctly putit, there's no gain without pain.
how into words
It is hard toput into wordshow I feel now.
how to put it
She wanted to tell him that she didn't want to see him any more, but she didn't knowhow toputit
The subject matter makes the painting a little,how shall I put it, undesirable for public display.
put it this wayspoken use this when you are trying to say sth in the clearest possible way
Put it this way: if we don’t make a profit, we’re out of a job.
put it like that
So it was an accident, an ‘act of God’ if you want toput it like that.
put it another way
It’s fairly risky. Orto put it another way(= say it in different words ), don’t try this at home.
If you don’t understand, I’ll try and put it another way.
to put it bluntly/briefly/simply etc
Their performance was, to put it bluntly, atrocious.
He’s not very musical,to put it mildly(= he’s not musical at all ).

children.name: utter
children.definition: formalto say sth : nói ra
examples: ‘You fool!’ she uttered in disgust.
without uttering a word
She sat through the whole meeting without uttering a word.
Cantor nodded withoututteringaword.

children.name: to take back what you have said
take back
children.definition: to say that sth you said previously is not true, especially because you now know it was unfair or wrong to say it:rút lại
examples: I want to take back some of the things I said yesterday.
If you don’t take that back I’ll never speak to you again.
take it all back
All right, I take it all back. It wasn't your fault.
Look, I’m sorry I accused you -- I take it all back.

children.name: withdraw
children.definition: formalif you withdraw a remark, criticism, statement etc, you say that what you said earlier was completely untrueSYN retract:thu hồi, rút lại
examples: He refused to withdraw his remarks and was expelled from the Party.
The newspaper has agreed to withdraw its allegations.
withdraw sth unreservedlywithdraw it completelyhoàn toàn thu hồi lại
Mary said that she was very sorry and that she withdrew the accusation unreservedly.

children.name: retract
children.definition: formal to formally or officially state that sth you previously said is not true: rút lại
examples: He confessed to the murder then later retracted his statement.
Galileo was not the first scientist to be forced to retract his theories.

children.name: can’t speak
children.definition: /ˌkɑːnt ˈspiːkǁˌkænt-/  to be unable to speak because you are too ill, weak, frightened etc:
examples: ▪ I was so terrified, I couldn’t speak.
▪ A lump welled up in his throat and he could not speak.

children.name: lose your voice
children.definition: /ˌluːz jɔːʳ ˈvɔɪs/  to become unable to speak because of illness, or because you have been using your voice too much:
examples: mất giọng
▪ On the first night of the show, the star of the play lost his voice and couldn’t perform.

children.name: dumb
children.definition: unable to speak, because you are angry, surprised, shocked etc : cứng họng
examples: He stared at the burnt-out car in dumb disbelief.
struck dumb: chết lặng
She wasstruck dumbwith terror.
She was struck dumb by what she had seen.
According to the story, he was struck dumb made dumb by the gods

children.name: be at a loss for words
children.definition: /be lost for words/biː ət ə ˌlɒs fəʳ ˈwɜːʳdzǁ-ˌlɔːs-, biː ˌlɒst fəʳ ˈwɜːʳdzǁ-ˌlɔːst-/  to be unable to say anything because you are very surprised, upset etc:
examples: ▪ Rimes, who is rarely at a loss for words, was overcome with emotion as she received her award.

children.name: to say sth in an indirect way
imply
children.definition: to say sth that seems to mean that another thing is true, but without saying the other thing directly:ngụ ý, hàm ý
examples: You seem to be implying something that is not quite true.
imply (that)
Michael did imply that I could have the job if I wanted it.
The article implied that unemployed people are lazy and do not want to work.
implication[C or U] C2 a suggestion that is not made directly but that people are expected to understand or accept
by implication
The law bans organized protests and, by implication, any form of opposition.
the implication is that(= which is meant to suggest that )
They are called ‘Supertrams’,the implication being thatthey are more advanced than earlier models.

children.name: suggest
children.definition: to say sth in an indirect way, especially sth bad that you prefer not to say directly:có ý
examples: What are you suggesting? Do you think I’m a thief?
Are you suggesting my husband’s been drinking?
suggest (that)
His letter seemed to suggest that he wasn’t satisfied with my work.
I’m not suggesting
used for telling someone you are not criticizing them
I’m not suggesting you deliberately tried to mislead us, just that you made a mistake.

children.name: hint
children.definition: to say sth in a very indirect way, so that other people can guess what you mean:gợi ý
examples: hint (that)
He hinted strongly that he might be prepared to send troops in.
hint at
What are you hinting at?
The President hinted at the possibility of military action.
hint[C]sththat you say or do to suggest sth to sb, without telling them directly :
‘Look, I can’t tell you.’ ‘Oh, come on,givemea hint.’
hint about/as to
Miles had beendroppingheavyhintsabout the cost of petrol.
hint that
There have beenhints thathe may take up coaching.
give (sb) a hintCome on, what is it? Give me a hint.
drop a hint(= give a hint )She was dropping quite a few hints about what she'd like for her birthday.
take a/the hint(= to understand a hint and act on it )Mark took the hint and shut up.
get the hint(= to understand a hint )I looked hopefully at the cake, but he didn't get the hint.
a broad/strong/heavy hint(= one that is very easy to understand )He had dropped a heavy hint that they might get married.
a subtle/gentle hint(= one that is not very easy to understand – sometimes used ironically when someone is being very obvious )I'm sick of her subtle hints that I'm not welcome here.
a vague hint(= one that is not specific enough to understand )In his article, he gave only vague hints as to what he had actually done.
I can take a hint(= used when you understand someone's hint )All right, I can take a hint. I'm leaving.

children.name: roundabout
children.definition: in a  way if you say sth in a roundabout way, you say it in an indirect way, especially to avoid offending or embarrassing sb:đường vòng
examples: I told him, in a roundabout way, that he wasn’t really good enough to join my English class.

children.name: rumour has it
children.definition: UK/rumorhasitUS spoken say this when you are telling sb sth that you heard from sb else, which may not actually be true: có lời đồn, người ta đồn
examples: To join the club, rumor had it, you had to be earning more than $100,000 a year.
rumour has it (that)
Rumour had it that she only married him for his money.

children.name: people say
children.definition: they say/ spoken use this to say what a lot of people believe and say:người ta nói
examples: Well,you know what they say– blood’s thicker than water.
The rest,as they say, is history.
they say/ people say (that)
They say her husband’s in prison.
so they sayuse this when you are not sure whether sth is true mọi người nói thế
The test isn’t difficult, or so they say.
"It's going to be a very hot summer." "Sothey say (= That is what people believe) ."
some might say(= some people believe)
She is a firm leader, too firm,some mightsay.

children.name: apparently
children.definition: used to say that you have heard that sth is true, although you are not completely sure about it : hình như
examples: Apparently the company is losing a lot of money.
I wasn’t there, but apparently it went well.
It’s going to be hot this weekend, apparently.
Apparently, Jim’s a really good tennis player.

children.name: there is talk of
children.definition: spoken use this to tell sb about what may happen in the future, that you have heard other people talking about: có lời đồn là
examples: He was doing very well at college and there was talk of him being accepted for Harvard.
The company already does business with Germany and Japan and there’s been some talk of a deal with the French.

children.name: supposedly
children.definition: spoken used when saying what many people say or believe is true, especially when you disagree with them :nghe như là, được cho là
examples: Richard was supposedly a tall, dark-eyed handsome man.
He was supposedly delivering some papers to her but I think it was just an excuse to see her.
How could a supposedly intelligent person be so stupid?
[sentence adv]
Anne is coming for a visit in March, supposedly.

children.name: it is said
children.definition: say when sth or sb is said to be a particular thing, that is what people think or believe about them
examples: it is said (that)
It is said that he was a spy during the war.
Itis said(that)Latin is a difficult language to learn.
sb is said to be/do
He’s said to be the richest man in the world.
He's saidto beover 100.

children.name: to add more to what have been said
add
children.definition: to say sth more, after what has already been said or written:thêm vào, bổ sung
examples: Is there anything you’d like to add, Peter?
‘Finally’, she added, ‘I would like to thank my family for their support’.
add that
I should add that I do not agree with Doctor Mitchell.
I hasten to add(= used to explain more about what you have just said ).
I was refused accommodation – not,I hasten to add, on account of my appearance
I might add(= used to comment on what you have just said ) xin phép bổ sung
She was trying to entertain us – unsuccessfully,I might add.

children.name: utter
children.definition: formalto make a sound with your voice, especially with difficulty : thốt ra, thốt lên
examples: The wounded prisoner uttered a groan.

children.name: say
children.definition: show/be a sign of something
examples: a)to show clearly that something is true about someone or something’s character :
The kind of car you drive says what kind of person you are.
The fact that she never apologizedsays a lot about(= shows very clearly )what kind of person she is.
It said a lot forthe manager(= it showed that he is good )that the team remained confident despite losing.
These resultsdon’t say much forthe quality of teaching(= they show that it is not very good ).
b)to show what someone is really feeling or thinking, especially without using words :
The look on her face said ‘I love you.’
sth says everything/says it all
His expression said it all.

children.name: to produce words using your voice
speak
children.definition: /spiːk/  to produce words with your voice.Speakis a little more formal thantalk.You often use it when saying that sbspeaksin a particular way
examples: How old are babies when they learn to speak?
Sean didn’t speak the whole time we were in the car
Don’t interrupt me when I’m speaking.
speak upspeak louder
Can you speak up? -- I can’t hear you.

children.name: talk
children.definition: to produce words and express thoughts, opinions, ideas etc : nói, nói chyện
examples: She was talking so fast I could hardly understand her.
You’re not supposed to talk in the library.
Please don’t all talk at the same time.
Some residents were frightened to talk publicly.
learn to talk
How do babieslearn to talk?
talk (in) French/German etc
They started talking in Spanish.
talk like that
Don’t let Dad hear youtalking like that(= expressing things in a particular way).

children.name: of sth written: to give information
say
children.definition: to give information in the form of written words, numbers, or pictures – used about signs, clocks, letters, messages etc :
examples: The sign said ‘Back in 10 minutes’.
The clock said twenty past three.
say (that)
He received a letter saying that the appointment had been cancelled.
say to do sth(= give information about what you should do )
The label says to take one tablet before meals.
say who/what/how etc
The card doesn’t even say who sent the flowers.
It says herethey have live music.

children.name: to speak the written part of sth
say
children.definition: to speak the words that are written in a play, poem, or prayer :
examples: Can you say that line again, this time with more feeling?
say a prayer
I’llsay a prayer foryou.
